title: Sec. 26-161.
text: It shall be the duty of every citizen of the town to assist the police chief or other municipal officer to arrest violators of the law when requested, and it shall be unlawful for any person to fail to do so. (Code 1981, § 136.01; Code 1998, § 28-171)

title: Sec. 26-162.
text: Any person who shall resist or obstruct any officer of the town in the discharge of his duty, or who shall aid or abet any person in resisting or obstructing any officer of the town in the discharge of his duty, shall be deemed guilty of a misdemeanor, subject to the limitations prescribed by S.C. Code 1976, § 16-5-50. Speech alone that questions or expresses opposition to police action does not constitute a violation of this section. (Code 1981, § 136.05; Code 1998, § 28-172)

title: Sec. 26-163.
text: It shall be unlawful for any person under arrest by municipal officials or for any prisoner of the town to make or effect his escape, or to endeavor or attempt to do so, or for any person to aid, abet, encourage or procure any such person under arrest or any other prisoner to do so. (Code 1981, § 136.07; Code 1998, § 28-173) State Law reference— Similar provisions, S.C. Code 1976, § 16-9-410.

title: Sec. 26-164.
text: It shall be unlawful for any person to loiter about the municipal jail or communicate in any way with the prisoners therein without the consent of the police officer on duty. (Code 1981, § 136.08; Code 1998, § 28-174)

title: Sec. 26-165.
text: It shall be unlawful for any person to talk to or communicate in any way with any prisoner confined in the municipal jail unless they first obtain permission, in writing, from the mayor, chief of police or jailer. (Code 1981, § 136.09; Code 1998, § 28-175)

title: Sec. 26-166.
text: (a) Any person who shall resist or obstruct any officer of the town in the discharge of his duty, or who shall aid or abet any person in resisting or obstructing any officer of the town in the discharge of his duty, shall be deemed guilty of a misdemeanor. Speech alone that questions or expresses opposition to police or other enforcement action does not constitute interference. (b) It shall be unlawful for any person to curse or abuse any police officer while that police officer is on duty in the town. Continued cursing or abuse after arrest shall also be an offense under this section. (Code 1981, § 136.15; Code 1998, § 28-176)

title: Sec. 26-167.
text: It shall be unlawful for any person to interrupt the proceedings of any court or any meeting of the council, or be guilty of disorderly conduct therein, or to commit any contempt of either. (Code 1981, § 136.16; Code 1998, § 28-177)

title: Sec. 26-168.
text: It shall be unlawful for any person knowingly to provide false information to any official, officer, employee or representative of the town on any matter pertaining to or affected by his official duties with the town. It also shall be unlawful for any person to conceal his identity, or to falsely identify himself in response to any inquiry by any official, officer, employee or representative of the town in connection with the performance of his official duties with the town. (Ord. of 6-18-2012, § 28-180)

title: ARTICLE V.
text: Footnotes: --- (5) --- State Law reference— Offenses involving weapons, S.C. Code 1976, § 16-23-10 et seq.

title: Sec. 26-190.
text: It shall be unlawful for any person to carry concealed about his person in the town any dirk, metal knuckles, razor, icepick, hawkbill knife, or any spring or clasp knife, which has a blade more than three inches in length, or other weapon usually used for the infliction of personal injuries. The weapon so carried concealed shall be forfeited to the town on conviction of a violation of this section. (Code 1981, § 137.01; Code 1998, § 28-211) State Law reference— Similar provisions, S.C. Code 1976, § 16-23-460.

title: Sec. 26-191.
text: It shall be unlawful to fire or discharge within the municipal limits any air rifle, pellet gun or other device that may be potentially harmful to any person or property. Any device used within the town in violation of this section is declared to be contraband, and such device shall be seized by the police and sold or destroyed. (Code 1981, § 137.03; Code 1998, § 28-213)

title: Sec. 26-200.
text: The accumulation and storage of abandoned or derelict motor vehicles is hereby found to create an undue and unnecessary traffic hazard, when on public streets, and an unsightly and unwarranted condition, when on private premises, tending to reduce value of private property, to invite plundering, to create fire hazards, and to constitute an attractive nuisance creating a hazard to the health and safety of minors. Such accumulation and storage of vehicles is further found to promote urban blight and deterioration in the community; to violate the zoning regulations of the city in many instances, particularly where such vehicles are maintained in the required front or side yard areas of residential property; and that such abandoned or derelict motor vehicles are in the nature of rubbish, litter, and unsightly debris in violation of health and sanitation laws. Therefore, the abandonment, accumulation or storage of such vehicles on public streets or on private property is hereby declared to constitute a public nuisance which may be adapted as such, which remedy shall be cumulative and in addition to any other remedy provided by law. (Ord. of 2-15-2021)

title: Sec. 26-201.
text: (a) The provisions of this article shall not apply to junkyards operated by duty licensed dealers, whose operations are regulated by chapter 12 of this Code. (b) The provisions of this article shall not apply to vehicles which bear a current "antique" vehicle license as issued by the South Carolina Department of Highways and Public Transportation. (Ord. of 2-15-2021)

title: Sec. 26-202.
text: No person shall park, store or leave, or permit the parking, storage or leaving of any abandoned or derelict vehicle or any vehicle which is in a rusted, wrecked, junked, partially dismantled or inoperative condition upon any public street within the city for a period in excess of 48 hours, or on any private property within the city for a period in excess of seven days. Not more than one derelict vehicle may be allowed, however, on any occupied one- and two-family private property, provided it is located in the rear yard as defined by zoning regulations, is housed or protected from the elements and is, along with the area within ten feet of such vehicle, maintained free of unsafe, unsanitary or unsightly conditions. If such vehicle is not completely enclosed within a structure, it shall be covered by a material specifically designed as a vehicle cover. The cover must be properly maintained free of defects, must cover the entire vehicle and must be properly secured to prevent removal by wind or other elements. No derelict or abandoned vehicles may be stored or placed for any length of time on nonresidential properties unless derelict or abandoned vehicles are considered customarily accessory to the use of such property. In addition, no derelict or abandoned vehicles may be stored or placed for any length of time on any vacant lots of land, property zoned as a manufactured home park or a multifamily district. Enforcement of the provisions of this article may be suspended for a period not exceeding 60 days upon issuance by the chief of police of a permit authorizing offering of a vehicle for sale, where such vehicle is operable but does not bear a current license tag. (Ord. of 2-15-2021)

title: Sec. 26-203.
text: Whenever it shall appear that a violation of the provisions of this article exists in reference to any vehicle situated upon any public street or on private property, the chief of police or officer shall cause a colored tag to be placed on the motor vehicle which shall be notice to the owner, the person in possession of the motor vehicle or any lienholder, that it is considered to be derelict or abandoned and is subject to forfeiture to the city. The colored tag shall serve as the only legal notice that if the vehicle is not removed within 48 hours from the date and time of the tag when located upon any public street and within seven days from the date and time of the tag when located on private property, it shall become the property of the city, and it will be removed to a designated place to be sold. It shall be unlawful for any person to tamper with, remove or destroy any colored tag placed on any vehicle pursuant to the provisions of this article. (1) Upon the expiration of the appropriate time period as outlined above, the chief of police or officer or building official or code enforcement officer shall cause the vehicle to be towed pursuant to the established towing procedure of the Great Falls Police Department. (2) Within ten days following the towing of a vehicle, the proprietor, owner, or operator of any towing company, storage facility, garage, or repair shop must provide to the sheriff or chief of police a list describing the vehicles remaining in the possession of the proprietor, owner, or operator of the towing company, storage facility, garage, or repair shop. A person who fails to provide the police department with this list forfeits recovery of any storage fees that have accrued from the date of towing until the day after the mailing of the notification to the owner and all lienholders by certified or registered mail, return receipt requested, pursuant to S.C. Code 1976, § 29-15-10. (3) Within ten days of receipt of this list, the chief of police will provide to the towing company or storage facility the current owner's name, address, and a record of all lienholders along with the make, model, and identification number or a description of the vehicle at no cost to the proprietor, owner, or operator of the towing company, storage facility, garage, or repair shop. The proprietor, owner, or operator of the towing company, storage facility, garage, or repair shop having towed or received the vehicle must notify by registered or certified mail, return receipt requested, the last known registered owner and all lienholders of record that the vehicle has been taken into custody. (4) If the identity of the last registered owner cannot be determined, or if the registration contains no address for the owner, or if it is impossible to determine with reasonable certainty the identity and addresses of all lienholders, the proprietor, owner, or operator of the towing company, storage facility, garage, or repair shop must provide notice by one publication in one newspaper of general circulation in the Lancaster area which is sufficient to meet all requirements of notice pursuant to this article. The notice by publication may contain multiple listings of abandoned vehicles. (5) Before a vehicle is sold, the proprietor, owner, or operator of the towing company, storage facility, garage, or repair shop must apply to the appropriate titling facility including, but not limited to, the department of motor vehicles or the department of natural resources for the name and address of any owner or lienholder. For nontitled vehicles, where the owner's name is known, a search must be conducted through the secretary of state's office to determine any lienholders. The application must be on prescribed forms as required by the appropriate titling facility or the secretary of state. If the vehicle has an out-of-state registration, an application must be made to that state's appropriate titling facility. When the vehicle is not titled in this state and does not have a registration from another state, the proprietor, owner, or operator of the towing company, storage facility, garage, or repair shop may apply to the chief of police for determination of the state where the vehicle is registered. The sheriff or chief of police shall conduct a records search. This search must include, but is not limited to, a search on the National Crime Information Center and any other appropriate search that may be conducted with the vehicle's identification number. The chief of police must supply, at no cost to the proprietor, owner, or operator of the towing company, storage facility, garage, or repair shop, the name of the state in which the vehicle is titled. (6) The proprietor, owner, or operator of the towing company, storage facility, garage, or repair shop that has towed and stored a vehicle has a lien against the vehicle and may have the vehicle sold at public auction pursuant to S.C. Code 1976, § 29-15-10. The proprietor, owner, or operator of the towing company, storage facility, garage, or repair shop may hold the license tag of any vehicle until all towing and storage costs have been paid, or if the vehicle is not reclaimed, until it is declared abandoned and sold. Storage costs may be charged that have accrued before the notification of the owner and lienholder, by certified or registered mail, of the location of the vehicle. Notification to the owner and lienholder by the proprietor, owner, or operator of the towing company, storage facility, garage, or repair shop must occur within five days after receiving the owner's and lienholders' identities from the appropriate law enforcement agency. If the notice is not mailed within this period, storage costs after the five-day period must not be charged until the notice is mailed. if the vehicle is not reclaimed within 30 days after the day the notice is mailed, return receipt requested, the vehicle is considered abandoned and may be sold by the magistrate pursuant to the procedures set forth in S.C. Code 1976, § 29-15-10. (7) After the vehicle is in the possession of the proprietor, owner, or operator of the towing company, storage facility, garage, or repair shop, the owner of the vehicle as demonstrated by providing a certificate of registration has one opportunity to remove from the vehicle any personal property not attached to the vehicle. The proprietor, owner, or operator of the towing company, storage facility, garage, or repair shop must release any personal property that does not belong to the owner of the vehicle to the owner of the personal property. (8) If an abandoned vehicle has not been reclaimed as provided for in S.C. Code 1976, § 56-5-5630, the proprietor, owner, or operator of the towing company, storage facility, garage, or repair shop may have the abandoned vehicle sold at a public auction pursuant to the provisions set forth in S.C. Code 1976, § 29-15-10. The purchaser of the vehicle shall take title to it free and clear of all liens and claims of ownership, shall receive a magistrate's order of sale, and is entitled to register the purchased vehicle and receive a certificate of title. The order of sale given at the sale must be sufficient title for purposes of transferring the vehicle to a demolisher for demolition, wrecking, or dismantling, and in this case no further titling of the vehicle is necessary. The expenses of the auction, the costs of towing, preserving, and storing the vehicle which resulted from placing the vehicle in custody, and all notice and publication costs incurred pursuant to the provisions of S.C. Code 1976, § 29-15-10, must be reimbursed up to the amount of the auction sale price from the sale proceeds of the vehicle. Any remainder of the sale proceeds must be held for the owner of the vehicle or entitled lienholder for 90 days. The magistrate must notify the owner and all lienholders by certified or registered mail, return receipt requested, that the vehicle owner or lienholder has 90 days to claim the proceeds from the sale of the vehicle. If the vehicle proceeds are not collected within 90 days from the day after the notice to the owner and all lienholders is mailed, then the vehicle proceeds must be deposited in the general fund of the county or municipality. (Ord. of 2-15-2021)

title: Sec. 26-204.
text: The chief of police is vested with the power and is charged with duties of administering the provisions of this article. The city may adopt such rules and regulations as may be necessary to carry out the provisions of this article. (Ord. of 2-15-2021)

title: Sec. 26-205.
text: The chief of police, his officers, the building official and his inspectors, are hereby expressly authorized to enter upon private property for the purpose of enforcing the provisions of this article. It shall be unlawful for any person to interfere with, hinder or refuse to allow any public official to enter upon private property for the purpose of enforcing the provisions of this article. (Ord. of 2-15-2021)

title: Sec. 26-206.
text: Any person who fails, neglects or refuses to remove the abandoned, wrecked, junked, partially dismantled or inoperative motor vehicle, or to house such vehicle and abate such nuisance in accordance with the notice given pursuant to the provisions of sections 26-202 and 26-203, shall be guilty of a misdemeanor. (Ord. of 2-15-2021)

title: Sec. 26-207.
text: Any person violating the provisions of this article shall be punished by a fine and shall pay all costs of vehicle removal, storage and disposal to the extent such costs have not been recovered by the city at the time of conviction, or imprisonment, or both as provided in section 1-7 of the City Code. Each day of violation shall constitute a separate offense. (Ord. of 2-15-2021)

title: Chapter 28
text: Footnotes: --- (1) --- State Law reference— Peddlers and hawkers, S.C. Code 1976, § 40-41-10 et seq.

title: Sec. 28-1.
text: It shall be unlawful for any person to beg or solicit money for the benefit of any charitable cause without first obtaining approval and a written permit from the chief of police. (Code 1981, § 110.01; Code 1998, § 30-1) State Law reference— Solicitation of Charitable Funds Act, S.C. Code 1976, § 33-56-10 et seq.

title: Sec. 28-2.
text: The practice by solicitors, vendors of merchandise, and the like of going in and upon the residences or private premises in the town, not having been requested or invited to do so by the owner or occupant of the premises, for the purpose of selling their wares and merchandise, disposing of, peddling or hawking the same is declared a nuisance and punishable as a misdemeanor. (Code 1981, § 110.02; Code 1998, § 30-2)

title: Chapter 30

title: Sec. 30-19.
text: The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: Commission means the planning and zoning commission. (Code 1998, § 32-31)

title: Sec. 30-20.
text: In order to guide and accomplish a coordinated and harmonious development of the town that will, in accordance with existing and future needs, best promote the public health, safety, morals, order, convenience, prosperity and the general welfare, as well as efficiency and economy in the process of development, the planning and zoning commission is created and established and the commission shall be organized, empowered and governed by the provisions of this article. (Code 1981, § 152.01; Code 1998, § 32-32)

title: Sec. 30-21.
text: The commission shall consist of five members to be appointed by the council. The terms of office of the members shall be for staggered terms of four years. Any vacancy in membership shall be filled for the unexpired term by the mayor, who shall also have the authority to remove any member for cause, on written charges, after a public hearing. All members shall serve without compensation but may be reimbursed for actual expenses incurred in connection with their official duties. (Code 1981, § 152.02; Code 1998, § 32-33)

title: Sec. 30-22.
text: (a) The commission shall elect a chair and vice-chair from among its members. The term of the chair and other officers shall be one year with eligibility for reelection. It shall appoint a secretary, who may be an officer or any employee of the governing authority or of the commission. (b) The commission shall adopt rules for the transaction of business and shall keep a record of its recommendations, transactions, findings and determinations, and shall meet at the call of the chair at such times as the chair or commission may determine. All meetings of the commission at which official action is taken shall be open to the public and all records of the commission shall be a public record. (c) The commission may appoint such employees and staff as it may deem necessary for its work and may make expenditures for salaries of any employees and staff, for contracts with consultants, and for the purchase of required equipment and supplies. The expenditures of the commission, exclusive of gifts, shall be within the amounts appropriated for that purpose by the council. (Code 1981, § 152.03; Code 1998, § 32-34)

title: Sec. 30-23.
text: The commission shall have all the powers, duties and responsibilities set forth in S.C. Code 1976, § 6-29-340. In general, the commission shall have the power to: (1) Prepare and revise periodically a comprehensive plan and program for the development of its jurisdiction as provided in this article. (2) Prepare and recommend for adoption to the appropriate governing authority or authorities as a means for implementing the plan and program: a. Zoning ordinances or resolutions, and maps and appropriate revisions thereof for its jurisdiction, as provided in this article. b. Regulations for the subdivision of land and appropriate revisions thereof within its jurisdiction, and administer the regulations that may be adopted as provided in this article. c. An official map and appropriate revisions thereof showing the exact location of existing or proposed public street, highway and utility rights-of-way and public building sites, together with regulations to control the erection of building or other structures or changes in land use within such rights-of-way, building sites or open spaces within its political jurisdiction or a specified portion thereof, as set forth in this article. (3) Establish principles and policies for guiding action in the development of the area. (4) Prepare and recommend to the council for adoption of ordinances promoting orderly development in accordance with the comprehensive plan. (5) Determine whether specific proposed developments conform to the principles and requirements of the comprehensive plan for the growth and improvement of the area. (6) Review and recommend to the council any needed changes in the zoning ordinance and the map of the town. (7) Prepare and recommend for adoption subdivision regulations and administer such regulations. (8) Keep the council and the general public informed and advised as to these matters. (Code 1981, § 152.04; Code 1998, § 32-35)

title: Chapter 32
text: Footnotes: --- (1) --- State Law reference— Municipalities required to adopt reasonable regulations, S.C. Code 1976, § 11-35-50.

title: ARTICLE II.

title: Sec. 32-19.
text: The provisions of this article are adopted to S.C. Code 1976, § 11-35-50 and may be referred to as the "town procurement code." The procurement code shall be implemented by the mayor who is authorized to issue regulations for procurement consistent with this Code. (Ord. of 4-19-2021)

title: Sec. 32-20.
text: The mayor or municipal clerk shall be the town purchasing agent. (Ord. of 4-19-2021)

title: Sec. 32-21.
text: Where procurement involves expenditure of state or federal funds subject to procurement regulations which are more restrictive than the town procurement code, the state or federal regulations shall be followed. (Ord. of 4-19-2021)

title: Sec. 32-22.
text: All town contracts shall be awarded by competitive sealed bidding except contracts for the following procurements: (1) Professional services where the person is engaged is customarily employed on a fee basis rather than competitive bidding (e.g., appraiser, architect, auditor, consultant, engineer, legal services, physician); (2) Proposals invited on a competitive sealed basis; (3) Negotiations after unsuccessful competitive sealed bidding: (4) Small purchases under $1,000; (5) Procurements under $5,000 documented by written quotations from two qualified sources of supply and a written determination by the municipal clerk or mayor that the procurement is to advantage of the town; (6) Procurements under $10,000 documented by written quotations from three qualified sources of supply and a written determination by the mayor and the municipal clerk that the procurement is to advantage of the town; (7) Blanket purchase agreements approved by the mayor or municipal clerk for repetitive small purchases on a charge account basis not requiring a purchase order for each purchase; (8) Sole source procurements approved by the mayor or municipal clerk when there is only a single supplier, compatibility of equipment or parts is the paramount consideration, the item is one of a kind, or the procurement is for printed material; (9) Procurements in emergency situations declared by the mayor to involve a threat to public health, safety, or welfare; (10) Procurement of information technology; (11) Leasing or purchasing of real property; or (12) Purchasing through state contracts. (Ord. of 4-19-2021)

title: Sec. 32-23.
text: Procedures promulgated by the mayor shall provide for fair and equitable sealed bidding when applicable to procurements under this article. An invitation to bid or request for proposals may be canceled by notice at any time prior to the opening of bids or proposals. The determination of an award for a contract for more than $10,000.00 to the low responsible bidder shall be made by council after receiving the recommendations of the mayor. All invitations to bid shall include the provisions that the town reserves the right all bids. A tie bid between an in town firm and an out of town firm shall be awarded to the in-town firm. Other tie bids shall be resolved by the flip of a coin by the municipal clerk witnessed by the parties. (Ord. of 4-19-2021)

title: Sec. 32-24.
text: It is the policy of the town to provide minorities and women equal opportunity for participating in the town's contracting and procurement programs, including, but not limited to, employment and construction projects consistent with the laws of the State of South Carolina. It is further the policy of the town to prohibit discrimination against any person or business in pursuit of these opportunities on the basis of race, color, national origin, religion, sex, age, handicap or veteran status. It is further the policy of the town to conduct its contracting and procurement programs so as to prevent such discrimination and to resolve any and all claims of such discrimination. (Ord. of 4-19-2021)

title: Sec. 32-25.
text: Invitations to bid shall include procedures for the filling of protests by an actual or prospective bidder who is aggrieved in connection with the solicitation or award of a contract. (Ord. of 4-19-2021)

title: Sec. 32-26.
text: The mayor may issue a notice of debarment or suspension to a person or firm upon a determination, after reasonable notice and an opportunity to be heard, that there is cause for doing so in the best interest of the town. The determination of the mayor may be appealed to council by written notice filed with the municipal clerk within ten days after receipt of the determination. The causes for debarment or suspension shall include, but not be limited to: (1) Conviction of a criminal offense incident to obtaining or attempting to obtain a public or private contract, in the performance of such contract; (2) Conviction for embezzlement, theft, forgery, bribery, falsification or destruction of records, receiving stolen property, or any other offense indicating a lack of business integrity or professional honesty which currently, seriously, and directly affects responsibility as a town contractor; (3) Conviction under antitrust laws arising out of submission of bids or proposals; (4) A recent deliberate failure without good cause to perform in accordance with the terms of the contract; (5) Any other cause determined to be so serious and compelling as to affect responsilbilty as a town contractor, including debarment by another governmental entity. (Ord. of 4-19-2021)

title: Sec. 32-27.
text: Contractors shall procure and maintain for the duration of a contract insurance against claims for injuries to persons or damage to property which may arise from or in connection with the performances of work by the contractor, his agents, representatives, employees or subcontractors. Proof of insurance must be provided to the town prior to the award of the contract and the signed contract must include minimum levels of required insurance. (Ord. of 4-19-2021)

title: Sec. 34-19.
text: The following definitions shall apply in the interpretation and the enforcement of this article: Commercial solid waste means garbage, rubbish, and other refuse resulting from institutions and commercial concerns such as motels, hotels, stores, businesses, etc. Construction and demolition debris means any material such as lumber, brick, plaster, gutters, or other substances accumulated because of repairs or additions to existing buildings, construction of new buildings or demolition of existing structures. Garbage means the byproduct of animal or vegetable foodstuffs resulting from the handling, preparation, cooking and consumption of food, or other matter, which is subject to decomposition, decay, putrefaction, or the generation of noxious or offensive gases or odors, or which during or after decay may serve as breeding or feeding material for flies, insects, or animals. Household trash means waste accumulation of paper, sweepings, dust, rags, bottles, cans, or other matter of any kind, other than garbage, which is usually attendant to housekeeping. Industrial waste means solid waste resulting from an industrial process or manufacturing operation. Litter means garbage, refuse, waste materials or any other discarded, used, or unconsumed substance which is not handled as specified herein. Municipal solid waste means all waste or other discarded, used, or unconsumed substances generated by residences. Refuse is a collective term which encompasses all the solid wastes for the community. Special waste means all waste collected in bulk containers from industry and also that refuse resulting from either a commercial, industrial, or manufacturing operation which requires special handling, such as sawdust, steel springs, or other materials which would otherwise damage the town's refuse packers. (Ord. of 1-17-2023(1))

title: Sec. 34-20.
text: The town sanitation department shall administer residential, commercial, and industrial refuse removal. Commercial and industrial plants may transport waste from their operations to an approved sanitary landfill. (Ord. of 1-17-2023(1))

title: Sec. 34-21.
text: All mobile containers will be furnished by the town. No other container, besides the town's container, can be used within the town for residential household trash. (Ord. of 1-17-2023(1))

title: Sec. 34-22.
text: Mobile containers shall remain at assigned addresses. Residential garbage shall be collected weekly. All approved garbage waste generated by residences shall be deposited in the mobile container and contained in a bag. Containers shall be placed at the pickup point on the scheduled pickup day, which shall be that point on the property nearest to the route of the vehicles. (Ord. of 1-17-2023(1))

title: Sec. 34-23.
text: Commercial establishments shall utilize approved bulk containers as necessary for solid waste generated. These containers will be positioned at the establishments by the town to permit waste collection in the most expeditious manner. Commercial establishments are eligible to opt out of the town's service and contract with an outside firm. (Ord. of 1-17-2023(1))

title: Sec. 34-24.
text: Any household, commercial establishment or industry requiring handling of special waste shall be required to contract with an outside firm. (Ord. of 1-17-2023(1))

title: Sec. 34-25.
text: Containers furnished by the town shall remain the property of the town. Containers which are damaged, destroyed, or stolen through abuse, neglect, or improper use by the occupant or owner shall be replaced at the expense of the occupant or owner of the residence. Containers which are damaged, destroyed or stolen through no abuse, neglect, or improper use of the occupant or residence owner shall be repaired or replaced by the town at no charge. (Ord. of 1-17-2023(1))

title: Sec. 34-26.
text: It shall be the responsibility of each occupant to place refuse for collection at the time [and] in the manner as provided in this article. No employee of the town shall assist any occupant except at those residences approved for back-door service. All single-family or multifamily residential containers shall be placed at the curb for collection no earlier than 3:00 p.m. the day before collection. All containers shall be removed from the curb no later than sunset on the day of collection. Containers shall be kept in the rear of residence, or on the side of the residence if behind shrubbery or other suitable screening such that the containers are not readily visible from the street. (Ord. of 1-17-2023(1))

title: Sec. 34-27.
text: Excess waste above the capacity of the mobile container shall be deposited in collection bags approved by the Town of Great Falls and placed neatly beside the mobile container. The collection bags can be purchased at town hall for $2.00 per bag. Occupants may obtain a second container when excess waste is generated frequently. The cost of an additional container will be $120.00 per year. Payment is due July 1 st each year and billed on June 1 st . (Ord. of 1-17-2023(1))

title: Sec. 34-28.
text: The occupant or residence owner shall keep the assigned containers reasonably clean and free of water. (Ord. of 1-17-2023(1))

title: Sec. 34-29.
text: The occupant or user of any container shall keep the storage area and curbside pickup point free of litter. Containers shall not be filled beyond capacity. (Ord. of 1-17-2023(1))

title: Sec. 34-30.
text: (a) All tree limbs, branches, underbrush, and other yard waste, including leaves, shall be placed at, not in, the street or curb for collection so as not to block the sidewalk. Leaves shall be separated from all other yard waste. Tree branches to be collected shall be no greater than six inches in diameter and six feet in length and have a volume of no more than ten cubic yards without the prior consent of the sanitation supervisor. (b) Yard waste that will not fit in mobile containers will be placed on the depositor's property adjacent to the street, but not in the street, gutter, ditch, or sidewalk, nor on properties other than the premises of the depositor. (Ord. of 1-17-2023(1))

title: Sec. 34-31.
text: A mobile container shall not be used as a depository for bricks, blocks, rocks, ashes, acids, or any other item destructive to the container, from weight or corrosive action, or residue from residential or commercial construction. A contractor, carpenter, or builder must remove all trash incident to construction or alteration at his own expense. (Ord. of 1-17-2023(1))

title: Sec. 34-32.
text: No person shall deposit or cause to be deposited any form of solid waste on any public or private property. Solid waste shall be prepared and placed for collection as specified in this article. (Ord. of 1-17-2023(1))

title: Sec. 34-33.
text: No person shall interfere with or otherwise deter the normal collection process by tampering with containers or their contents. (Ord. of 1-17-2023(1))

title: Sec. 34-34.
text: Residential household trash containers shall be serviced once weekly. (Ord. of 1-17-2023(1))

title: Sec. 34-35.
text: Households where no one is physically able to roll the carts to the street for collection will be given back-door service by the sanitation department on a once-per-week basis. Applications for back-door service are available from town hall and shall be subject to approval by the sanitation supervisor. (Ord. of 1-17-2023(1))

title: Sec. 34-36.
text: Small dead animals shall be picked up on a call basis and shall not be placed in mobile containers. Owners of large dead animals shall be responsible for their removal and disposal. Dead animals shall be reported to the town hall and will be removed on weekdays between 6:00 a.m. and 2:00 p.m. (Ord. of 1-17-2023(1))

title: Sec. 34-37.
text: (a) It shall be unlawful for any person who is not contracted with the town to dispose or place waste in any receptacle, trash can, trash box or bin serviced by the town. (b) For the purposes of this section, waste does not include trash, litter, paper, or food products which can be casually carried and deposited by hand without being packaged or contained in a paper or plastic bag. (Ord. of 1-17-2023(1))

title: Sec. 34-38.
text: All mobile container service will be billed on a monthly basis and collected pursuant to the contract between the Town of Great Falls and the Chester Metropolitan District. If mobile container service is delinquent as described on the billing, then the town will discontinue the service, collect the containers, and pursue action necessary to collect the debt, including, but not limited to, civil action. Charges will be assessed for mobile container service and reinstatement service provided by the town as approved by the town council in the amount of $20.00. (Ord. of 1-17-2023(1))

title: Sec. 34-39.
text: Bulky materials, including, but not limited to, furniture or other brown goods, will be collected on a fee basis determined by the sanitation supervisor, [and] shall be placed at, not in, the street or curb for collection so as not to block the sidewalk. Bulky materials shall be separated from yard waste. Bulky materials, including furniture and other brown goods, shall be placed for collection on the premises of the depositor. The depositor is responsible to make arrangements and payment with the sanitation supervisor prior to placing bulky items for collection. (Ord. of 1-17-2023(1))

title: Sec. 34-40.
text: The town shall not collect hazardous refuse as defined in this article or shingles, batteries, paint, tires, mattresses, appliances, bricks, rocks, dirt, sheetrock, sand, stone, concrete, automotive parts or other refuse not accepted at any South Carolina Department of Health and Environmental Control approved transfer station or landfill. (Ord. of 1-17-2023(1))

title: Chapter 36
text: Footnotes: --- (1) --- State Law reference— Municipal authority to regulate streets, S.C. Code 1976, § 5-7-30; putting foreign substances on highways, S.C. Code 1976, § 57-7-20; obstructions in highways, S.C. Code 1976, § 57-7-210.

title: Sec. 36-1.
text: It shall be the duty of all owners of real estate within the municipal limits to keep the sidewalks adjoining their real estate clear and free from grass, weeds, trash and garbage, these sidewalks to be cleared and the grass and weeds cut and removed therefrom at such times as the council shall direct. If any owner of real estate within the municipal limits shall neglect or refuse to cut the grass and weeds from the sidewalks adjoining his property when directed to do so or fail otherwise to keep such sidewalks clean and sanitary, the chief of police is authorized to employ such labor as may be necessary to clear and clean those sidewalks; and the charge for the same shall be due and payable by such property owner, to be collected as a municipal tax. (Code 1981, § 95.02; Code 1998, § 36-1)

title: Sec. 36-2.
text: All owners of land within the corporate limits shall keep in good repair the sidewalks adjacent to those lots, and the liability for damages arising from the failure to do so shall lie with the owners of the land. (Code 1981, § 95.03; Code 1998, § 36-2)

title: Sec. 36-3.
text: Whoever violates any provision of this chapter, for which no penalty is otherwise provided, shall be punished as provided in section 1-6. (Code 1981, § 95.99; Code 1998, § 36-3)

title: Sec. 36-25.
text: It shall be unlawful for any person to allow any trench, ditch or excavation in any street, sidewalk or public place to remain open between sunset and sunrise unless such trench, ditch or excavation has a sufficient number of lights properly displayed around it as danger signals to prevent accidents to persons or property. (Code 1981, § 95.26; Code 1998, § 36-36)

title: Sec. 36-26.
text: It shall be unlawful for any person to remove or extinguish any light that may be placed as a signal at night to warn persons of danger from ditches, trenches, building materials, scaffolds, excavations, impediments or obstacles of any description whatsoever. (Code 1981, § 95.27; Code 1998, § 36-37)

title: Sec. 36-27.
text: It shall be unlawful for any person to place any obstruction on or cause to be obstructed in any manner any street, sidewalk or public way or part thereof, so as to render the passage of persons, vehicles or other travel thereon difficult, inconvenient, dangerous or impossible except as otherwise provided in this article. This section shall not apply to any employee of the town, county or state while such employee is immediately and actively engaged in the maintenance, improvement or construction of any street, sidewalk or public way in the town. (Code 1981, § 95.28; Code 1998, § 36-38)

title: Sec. 36-28.
text: (a) On corner lots in the town, there shall be no obstruction to vision between a height of two feet and a height of ten feet measured above the average elevation of the existing surfaces of the intersecting streets at their centerlines, within the area formed by joining points on the property lines, measured as follows: (1) On property lines abutting streets 50 feet or less in right-of-way width, the points on the property lines shall be not less than 25 feet from the lot corner; and (2) On property lines abutting streets more than 50 feet in right-of-way width, the points on the property lines shall be 50 feet from the lot corner. (b) This restriction shall not apply to buildings in business districts. (Code 1981, § 95.29; Code 1998, § 36-39)

title: Sec. 36-29.
text: It shall be unlawful to plant, place or cause to grow any tree or shrub on any roadway or street right-of-way or in any area between a sidewalk and a curb of such street or roadway within the municipal limits. Furthermore, the council is authorized to order the removal of any such tree or shrub already growing in those areas on a determination by the chief of police that such tree or shrub is hazardous to traffic. (Code 1981, § 95.30; Code 1998, § 36-40)

title: Sec. 36-30.
text: Any person who cuts and piles any tree limbs and shrubs beside the streets and byways of the town, if he is employed by the landowner whose property adjoins the street, shall be liable for the removal of the limbs and shrubs. If the landowner himself shall cut the limbs, the town will transport the refuse to the landfill, without charge; but if one employed by the owner shall cut and pile the limbs, there will be a $20.00 per load charge for the removal of the limbs and shrubs. (Code 1981, § 95.31; Code 1998, § 36-41)

title: Sec. 36-49.
text: Any person building houses or other structures within the town may obtain from the mayor a builder's permit for a partial and temporary use of the public square and streets for building purposes. (Code 1981, § 95.45; Code 1998, § 36-71)

title: Sec. 36-50.
text: It shall be unlawful for any person to play football, baseball, basketball or other games in and on any street, park, square or any other public place in the town, except in the places provided therefor, unless with permission of chief of police and on a street blocked off by police. (Code 1981, § 95.06; Code 1998, § 36-72)

title: Sec. 36-51.
text: It shall be unlawful for any person to place or hang, or cause to be hung or placed, any banner or advertisement across any street in the town unless permission shall have been first obtained by such person from the council or chief of police. (Code 1981, § 95.20; Code 1998, § 36-73)

title: Sec. 36-76.
text: (a) Any person who wishes to organize any activity shall be required to register the activity with the chief of police at least 30 days in advance and to obtain a permit therefor. (b) Definition. The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: Activity means any march ceremony, demonstration, exhibition or festival of any kind upon any public street of the city. (c) Application for permit to conduct an activity shall be made to the chief of police in writing, shall be signed by the person applying for the permit and shall contain the following information: (1) Time of the activity. (2) Route of the activity or area to be closed. (3) The name and address of the person or organization sponsoring or promoting the activity. (d) Review of applications. The chief of police shall forward the application to the council who shall review the information set forth in the application. (e) Disposition. If the council determines that the proposed activity will unreasonably burden or interfere with the normal use of the streets or sidewalks the request will be denied, and if the council determines that the proposed activity will not unreasonably burden or interfere with the normal use of the streets and sidewalks the permit will be granted. (Code 1998, § 36-101; Ord. of 6-17-2013, § 1)

title: Sec. 36-77.
text: The chief of police shall issue a permit as provided for under this article when, from a consideration of the application and from any other information as may otherwise be obtained, he finds that: (1) The conduct of the activity will not interrupt the safety and orderly movement of other traffic. (2) The activity will not require a greater number of police officers than the chief can provide. (3) The activity will not prohibit emergency vehicle from providing service to portions of town not included in the closed town area. (4) The conduct of the activity will not likely cause injury to persons on property, or provoke disorderly conduct or create a disturbance. (Code 1998, § 36-102; Ord. of 6-17-2013, § 2)

title: Sec. 36-78.
text: The chief of police shall act upon the application for a permit within five working days at the filing thereof. If the chief of police disapproves the application, he shall mail to the applicant within ten days after the date upon which the application was filed, a notice of his action stating the reasons for his denial of the permit. (Code 1998, § 36-103; Ord. of 6-17-2013, § 3)

title: Sec. 38-1.
text: Whoever violates any provision of this chapter, for which no penalty is otherwise provided, shall be punished as provided in section 1-6. (Code 1981, § 96.99; Code 1998, § 38-1)

title: Sec. 38-2.
text: (a) The town imposes a local hospitality tax to be paid by the consumer or patrons of restaurants, lounges, other food establishments, grocery, convenience stores and any other establishment that sells prepared food and beverages. This tax will be based on two percent of the total gross sales price received for prepared food, meals and beverages sold. (b) Such establishments are required to open a hospitality tax account at the town hall, in order to remit monthly payment of two percent on their gross revenue. Monthly payments must be received no later than the 20th day of the following month. A report of total gross sales for the period must accompany the payment. The town clerk-treasurer is empowered to inspect, examine and/or audit books and records to ensure compliance and report accuracy. Failure to pay on time carries a penalty of five percent of the unpaid amount. A negative report is required if there is no gross revenue to report for the period. (c) The revenue generated by the hospitality tax will be kept in a separate fund segregated from the general fund. All interest generated by the local hospitality tax fund must be credited to the local hospitality fund. All proceeds will be used exclusively for any of the following purposes: (1) Tourism-related buildings including, but not limited to, civic centers, coliseums and aquariums; (2) Tourism-related cultural, recreational, or historic facilities; (3) Beach or waterways access and renourishment; (4) Highways, roads, streets, and bridges providing access to tourist destinations; (5) Advertisements and promotions related to tourism development; or (6) Water and sewer infrastructure to serve tourism-related demand. (Ord. of 2-18-2008) State Law reference— Local Hospitality Tax Act, S.C. Code 1976, § 6-1-700 et seq.

title: Sec. 38-23.
text: All new manufacturing establishments located in the town after October 1, 1986, and all additions to any existing manufacturing establishments, including additional machinery and equipment, located in the town after October 1, 1986, costing $50,000.00 or more, shall be exempt from municipal ad valorem taxes for not more than five years. (Code 1998, § 38-31; Ord. of 9-15-1986, § 1)

title: Sec. 38-24.
text: The owner of any manufacturing establishment seeking to obtain exemption from ad valorem taxes levied by the town shall apply to and comply with all requirements of the state tax commission for the exemption from local property taxes; the determination of the state tax commission that such new manufacturing establishment or any new additions, including machinery and equipment, is qualified to be exempt from local property taxes shall constitute a determination that such establishment is exempt from real and personal ad valorem taxes granted under the provisions of this article. (Code 1998, § 38-32; Ord. of 9-15-1986, § 2)

title: Sec. 38-25.
text: Pursuant to S.C. Code 1976, § 12-4-710 et seq., the exemption of a manufacturing establishment under the provisions of this article is granted for one year only; and each property owner shall reapply annually for tax exemption status with the state tax commission for not more than five exceptions. (Code 1998, § 38-33; Ord. of 9-15-1986, § 3)

title: Sec. 40-1.
text: This chapter may be known and cited as the traffic code. (Code 1981, § 70.01; Code 1998, § 40-1)

title: Sec. 40-2.
text: For the purposes of this chapter, the definitions in S.C. Code 1976, § 56-5-110 et seq. are adopted and made a part hereof as if fully set out herein. (Code 1981, § 70.02; Code 1998, § 40-2)

title: Sec. 40-3.
text: (a) The council, except as otherwise directed by this chapter, shall have the power and authority permitted by S.C. Code 1976, § 56-5-710 and shall have the power and authority to regulate the operation and parking of vehicles within the corporate limits by the erection or placement of proper signs or markers indicating: (1) Prohibited or limited parking; (2) Restricted speed areas; (3) One-way streets; (4) Play streets; (5) Through or arterial streets; (6) Parking meter spaces in parking meter zones; (7) U-turns; (8) School zones; (9) Hospital zones; (10) Loading and unloading zones; (11) Quiet zones; and (12) Other signs, markers and official traffic control devices indicating the place or manner of operating or parking vehicles. (b) The council, except as otherwise directed by this chapter, shall have power to regulate the movement of pedestrians on the streets and sidewalks by the erection or placement of proper signs or markers indicating the flow of pedestrian traffic. (c) The council, except as otherwise directed by this chapter, shall have power to designate bus stops and taxicab stands and to erect signs prohibiting the parking of vehicles other than buses and taxicabs at their respective stops and stands. (d) The council, except as otherwise directed by this chapter, shall have the power to mark off traffic lanes on streets and parts of streets indicating and directing the flow of traffic when in the judgment of the council, such action is necessary. (e) The council shall have power to secure all necessary signs, markers or official traffic control devices to be erected or placed on any street or part of a street when such action is deemed necessary. (f) The existence of such signs, markers or official traffic control devices at any place shall be prima facie evidence that these signs, markers or official traffic control devices were erected or placed by and at the direction of the council and in accordance with the provisions of this section. (Code 1981, § 70.04; Code 1998, § 40-4) State Law reference— Powers of local authorities, S.C. Code 1976, § 56-5-710.

title: Sec. 40-4.
text: (a) All vehicles shall be operated in accordance and conformity with S.C. Code 1976, §§ 56-3-110 et seq., 56-3-2320 et seq., 56-9-10 et seq., 56-1-10 et seq. and subsequent amendments thereto as relating to the operation of vehicles. These provisions are adopted by reference and made a part of this chapter as if set out in full herein, except those provisions relating solely to the state department of revenue and taxation and those provisions for which the penalty exceeds a fine of $500.00 or imprisonment for more than 30 days. (b) All requirements of S.C. Code 1976, § 56-5-10 et seq., the Uniform Act Regulating Traffic on the Highways, are adopted by reference and made a part of this chapter as if set out in full herein. (Code 1981, § 70.05; Code 1998, § 40-5)

title: Sec. 40-5.
text: No person shall allow, permit or let any vehicle registered in his name to violate any of the ordinances of the town, provided all violations of parking ordinances shall be presumed to be with the knowledge of the owner of such vehicle. (Code 1981, § 70.06; Code 1998, § 40-6)

title: Sec. 40-6.
text: (a) It shall be unlawful for any person driving a vehicle to use the driveway of any filling station or service station in the town as a roadway or thoroughfare, or to drive across any grass plot so as to mutilate things growing thereon. (b) It shall be unlawful for any person driving a vehicle to make any U-turn or other prohibited turn at any point where such turn is prohibited, and it shall be unlawful to accomplish a U-turn by deviously going into or through private property adjoining the street where such turn is prohibited. (Code 1981, § 70.07; Code 1998, § 40-7)

title: Sec. 40-7.
text: It shall be unlawful for any person to deliver or serve any drinks, cigars, cigarettes, candy, foods or sandwiches to any person occupying an automobile or other vehicle parked or standing on the streets of the town or the public highways. This section does not apply to private property. (Code 1981, § 76.01; Code 1998, § 40-8)

title: Sec. 40-8.
text: The owner or operator of every cart or other vehicle employed in removing or carrying any dirt, sawdust, sand, coal, material liable to be blown by the wind, or any manure, filth or offensive matter of any kind or description along or over any of the streets of the town shall have and keep the same in such tight and secure condition that such matter shall not be scattered or suffered to fall on any of the streets. (Code 1981, § 95.10; Code 1998, § 40-9)

title: Sec. 40-9.
text: It shall be unlawful for any person to ride, propel or park any automobile, motorcycle or other vehicle on any sidewalk of the town except as may be necessary in entering or leaving the premises or buildings. (Code 1981, § 95.11; Code 1998, § 40-10)

title: Sec. 40-10.
text: It shall be unlawful for any person to operate, drive or cause to be driven or operated over, on or across the paved streets, squares or thoroughfares of the town, a vehicle having wheels with flanges, ribs, clamps, spikes or other devices attached to or part of the wheel of such vehicle that would injure or damage the paved surface of any streets, squares or thoroughfares. (Code 1981, § 95.14; Code 1998, § 40-11)

title: Sec. 40-11.
text: Whoever violates any provision of this chapter for which no penalty is otherwise provided shall be punished as provided in section 1-6. (Code 1981, § 70.99; Code 1998, § 40-12)

title: Sec. 40-43.
text: No driver shall enter an intersection or a marked crosswalk unless there is sufficient space on the other side of the intersection or crosswalk to accommodate the vehicle he is operating without obstructing the passage of other vehicles or pedestrians, notwithstanding any traffic control signal indication to proceed. title: Sec. 40-44.
text: Immediately on the sounding of any warning designated by the town in case of fire or emergency, the driver of all vehicles, excepting the emergency vehicle, shall yield the right-of-way and shall immediately drive to a position parallel to, and as close as possible, to the right hand edge or curb of the roadway clear of any intersection and shall stop and remain in such position until the emergency vehicle has passed, except as otherwise directed by a police officer. (Code 1981, § 72.03; Code 1998, § 40-47) State Law reference— Similar provisions, S.C. Code 1976, § 56-5-2360.

title: Sec. 40-45.
text: It shall be unlawful for the driver of a vehicle to follow or attempt to follow any fire truck, police car, ambulance or rescue squad equipment on an emergency call at a distance closer than 500 feet or stop any vehicle within 500 feet of any fire apparatus stopped in answer to a fire alarm. (Code 1981, § 72.04; Code 1998, § 40-48) State Law reference— Similar provisions, S.C. Code 1976, § 56-5-1960.

title: Sec. 40-64.
text: Where parking is permitted on streets not marked off for parking, the operator of any vehicle shall park that vehicle with the right front and right rear wheels as near as possible to the curb and parallel thereto. Vehicles parked within marked areas shall not occupy any part of more than one space. The operator of any parked vehicle shall back out into the roadway only when the roadway is clear. (Code 1981, § 75.01; Code 1998, § 40-81)

title: Sec. 40-65.
text: (a) No person shall stop, stand or park any vehicle on a street other than an alley in such a manner or under such conditions as to obstruct the well-traveled portion of the roadway, except that a driver may stop temporarily during the actual loading or unloading of passengers or when necessary in obedience to traffic regulations, traffic signs or signals of a police officer. title: Sec. 40-66.
text: No person shall stand or park a vehicle alongside any roadway for the principal purpose of displaying it for sale or washing, greasing or repairing the vehicle except for repairs necessitated by an emergency. (Code 1981, § 75.03; Code 1998, § 40-83)

title: Sec. 40-67.
text: The council may, in its discretion, designate special parking places for doctors and any other persons for which sufficient cause is found to exist. (Code 1981, § 75.04; Code 1998, § 40-84)

title: Sec. 40-68.
text: (a) No person shall stop, stand or park a vehicle for any purpose or period of time other than for the expeditious unloading or loading of passengers in any place marked as a passenger zone during hours when the regulations applicable to such passenger zone are effective, and then only for a period not to exceed three minutes. (b) No person shall stop, stand or park a vehicle for any purpose or length of time other than for the expeditious unloading and delivery or pickup and loading of materials in any place marked as a loading zone. In no case shall the stop for unloading of materials exceed 30 minutes. (Code 1981, § 75.05; Code 1998, § 40-85)

title: Sec. 40-69.
text: Any motor vehicle remaining parked on a paved street for 12 hours after notice to remove has been given by a police officer shall be removed and stored at the owner's expense. The notice may be given to the owner or the agent in charge of the vehicle by leaving a copy of the notice on the vehicle or at the residence of the owner or agent.
